item.title: UK furlough scheme extended by four months
item.description: The scheme to pay wages of workers on leave because of coronavirus has been extended to the end of October.

item.title: Coronavirus: How many people have died in the UK?
item.description: Official statistics show a large increase in the number of UK deaths above the expected level.

item.title: Coronavirus: House moves and viewings to resume in England
item.description: The changes are part of the government's new lockdown measures which come into place from Wednesday.

item.title: Coronavirus: Royal Family thanks world's nurses in video calls
item.description: The Queen led the tributes to nurses, saying they have had "a very important part to play recently".

item.title: Nurse's emotional reunion with coronavirus patient
item.description: The surprise, virtual meeting brings back strong feelings and memories for the pair.

item.title: Coronavirus: Victoria ticket worker dies after being spat at
item.description: Belly Mujinga's husband says she was "a good person, a good mother, and a good wife".

item.title: Foreign holiday season likely to be cancelled, says minister
item.description: Health Secretary Matt Hancock says "big, lavish international holidays" are unlikely this summer.

item.title: Google Search results topped by suspected scam gadget store
item.description: The store listed hard-to-find technology and exercise equipment at discount prices and is now offline.

item.title: Afghan attack: US secretary of state condemns shooting at Kabul maternity ward
item.description: Mike Pompeo says the Kabul attack which killed two babies and 12 mothers and nurses was "sheer evil".

item.title: Coronavirus: How England's golf courses, tennis clubs and fisheries are preparing for return of sport
item.description: BBC Sport speaks to grassroots sport clubs as golf, tennis and fishing are among the sports set to start coming out of lockdown.

item.title: MPs urge UK ban on chlorinated chicken and hormone-fed beef
item.description: Hormone-fed beef and chlorine-washed chicken should remain banned in England. the government is warned.

item.title: Maria Branyas: 'Oldest woman in Spain' beats coronavirus at 113
item.description: Maria Branyas recovers after weeks in isolation, having experienced only mild symptoms.

item.title: Coronavirus: Holiday park booking requests surge
item.description: It says the rise follows the easing of restrictions in England, which do not apply in Wales.

item.title: Newspaper headlines: No 'cliff edge' and housing market 'kick-started'
item.description: The papers focus on the chancellor's announcement that the job retention scheme will be extended.

item.title: Coronavirus: Police forces deliver 12-year-old's PPE for grandmother
item.description: The Wiltshire and Northamptonshire forces help Cameron Douglas deliver his homemade face shields.

item.title: Blue Peter: New presenter to be unveiled during lockdown
item.description: Mwaka Mudenda will join the Blue Peter team virtually - and be tasked with breaking a world record.

item.title: Scrabble fans slam 'sparkly abomination' new app
item.description: A new app designed to replace the existing official Scrabble app has sparked hundreds of complaints.

item.title: Nurses: 'I don't know what we would do without them'
item.description: As the coronavirus pandemic continues, we ask what the role of a nurse means to those who need it.

item.title: Eurovision tribute by Fizz members and BBC correspondent
item.description: May 12 would have been the Eurovision semi-finals but the competition was cancelled due to coronavirus.

item.title: Coronavirus: How to socially distance on public transport
item.description: London’s transport authorities say travel is only for ‘essential journeys’ during the pandemic.

item.title: Michael Morpurgo's submission in The Book of Hopes aims to 'lift'
item.description: Michael Morpurgo is just one of more than 100 authors and illustrators who have contributed to The Book of Hopes.

item.title: Coronavirus: Four nurses on four continents tell their story
item.description: On International Nurses Day the BBC spoke to four nurses on four continents about fighting the coronavirus pandemic.

item.title: Coronavirus: How Sweden is keeping its pubs and bars open
item.description: Sweden never went into full lockdown following the Coronavirus outbreak, so how do bars stay open?

item.title: Coronavirus: Hairdressers among businesses to reopen in France
item.description: France has begun to ease its lockdown, and thousands of businesses have started to reopen.

item.title: International Nurses Day: The gran, mum and daughter on the front line
item.description: Meet three generations of a North East family working on the front line to fight coronavirus.

item.title: Coronavirus lockdown: Why garden centres reopened first
item.description: A national obsession and an industry at the mercy of the seasons meant it was time to (safely) open up.

item.title: Leaf Arbuthnot: How rent-a-gran scheme sparked a debut novel
item.description: Leaf Arbuthnot's story of intergenerational friendship makes for a debut apt for the here and now.

item.title: Coronavirus: 'I run lockdown marathons in the dead of night'
item.description: Runners tell of the dramatic ways their training has changed during the coronavirus lockdown.

item.title: Coronavirus: Are children at risk and do they spread it?
item.description: Children appear to be at low risk from the disease, but are they spreading it?

item.title: Face masks: How is Wales' advice different to England?
item.description: Wales is taking a different approach to the use of face masks than other UK nations.

item.title: Coronavirus: How lockdown rules differ in Northern Ireland
item.description: How Stormont's approach to easing restrictions differs from that taken by GB and the Republic of Ireland.

item.title: Playing tennis during coronavirus: What are the latest rules on safety?
item.description: One-to-one coaching, as well as a game of singles with someone from outside your household, will be permitted in England from Wednesday.

item.title: Coronavirus doctor's diary: 'They say I have blood on my hands'
item.description: Abusive messages were sent to an Asian doctor because of a myth that non-white patients are left to die.

item.title: Lockdown: ‘Noisy neighbours are ruining my life’
item.description: Several UK councils report a rise in noise complaints since the start of the lockdown.

item.title: Coronavirus: 'I could be forced to lose a job I love'
item.description: Short notice from the government about returning to work has caused problems for some.

item.title: The robot assistant that can guess what you want
item.description: In a five-year project a group of robotics experts have developed a robot that can assist in maintenance tasks.

item.title: Coronavirus: Seacole hospital 'a tribute' to BAME NHS staff
item.description: A new community hospital recognises Jamaican-born nurse Mary Seacole - and BAME staff who have died.

item.title: Joshna Maharaj - The chef who lost her sense of smell
item.description: Chef Joshna Maharaj couldn't smell for years. Now she's working to regain some of what she lost.

item.title: The tech industry's winners and losers in lockdown
item.description: Unprecedented times are bad news for many - but not all. Some major technology companies are thriving.

item.title: Coronavirus: What should my employer do to keep me safe?
item.description: The government has published new guidance on how workplaces should be made safe amid the pandemic.

item.title: No tackling and disinfected pitches - Premier League training protocols sent to clubs
item.description: Tackling will be banned, pitches disinfected, and players restricted to groups of five under Premier League guidance for an initial phase of team training.

item.title: 'After a minute it would be horrible' - Bunce verdict on Tyson comeback talk
item.description: As Mike Tyson stokes speculation he may return to boxing, 5 Live's Steve Bunce warns any real fight would prove "horrible".

item.title: 'Football shouldn't even be spoken about' - Rose criticises restart plans
item.description: England defender Danny Rose criticises the Premier League's plans to restart the season amid the coronavirus pandemic.

item.title: Amy Hunt: The British teenager who is faster than Dina Asher-Smith
item.description: Life comes at you fast when you are one of the quickest teenagers on earth, as sprinter, star student and Vogue model Amy Hunt is finding out.

item.title: Newcastle to make £53m bid for Bale - gossip
item.description: Newcastle to make £53m Gareth Bale move, Odion Ighalo blow for Manchester United, Dejan Lovren to Roma, plus more.

item.title: Tony Bellew: Ask British former heavyweight boxer your questions
item.description: Boxer, film actor, now reality TV star in SAS Who Dares Wins - ask former heavyweight world champion Tony Bellew your questions.

item.title: Coronavirus: What does it mean if I've been furloughed by work?
item.description: Millions unable to do their job due to coronavirus will have their wages paid by a new scheme.

item.title: Lockdown update: All you need to know about new measures
item.description: With more restrictions eased in England on Wednesday, how will social and work life be different?

item.title: Coronavirus: What are social distancing and self-isolation rules?
item.description: Boris Johnson has announced changes to guidelines in England on exercise and social distancing.

item.title: How do I travel to work now?
item.description: Some people are being encouraged to go back to work, but how will they get there?

item.title: How to make your own face mask
item.description: Our guide to different types of face coverings and step-by-step instructions on how to make them.

item.title: Coronavirus: Do I have to go back to work after lockdown?
item.description: With lockdown restrictions eased, people may start going back to work. But what are your rights?

item.title: Coronavirus: Can university students get a fee refund? And other questions
item.description: Can university students get a fee refund? and other questions answered by BBC experts.

item.title: Coronavirus: Who should wear a face mask or face covering?
item.description: For the first time, people in England are being advised to wear face coverings in some situations.

item.title: Coronavirus: When will schools reopen?
item.description: Schools have been closed to most pupils since the end of March - when and how will they open?

item.title: Coronavirus R0: What is the R number and why does it matter?
item.description: Experts keep discussing the value of R, but what is it and why does it matter?

item.title: Coronavirus: What is the UK's test, track and trace strategy?
item.description: A guide to the three key parts of the government's coronavirus strategy after lockdowns are eased.

item.title: Coronavirus: What are the new travel quarantine rules?
item.description: What do you need to know if you're planning to fly during the Covid-19 pandemic?

item.title: Coronavirus: Intensive care and other key terms explained
item.description: Use our tool to check the meaning of key words and phrases associated with the Covid-19 outbreak.

item.title: Coronavirus: How lockdown is being lifted across Europe
item.description: As the UK alters its restrictions, how do other European countries plan to re-open after lockdown?

item.title: Coronavirus: Labour's Starmer says PM statement 'raises as many questions as answers'
item.description: People are being told to go back to work without clear safety guidance, Labour leader Keir Starmer says.

item.title: 'I stole a plane to get out of the Navy'
item.description: When Theo Van Eijck was kicked out of a Dutch pilot-training programme in 1964, he stole a plane and flew to Libya.
